docs.title: Meaning
docs.text: それに can mean and in addition or and is also depending on the context.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
それに is used to connect two sentences. It is placed at the beginning of the second sentence.

Examples

  • 渡辺さんは優しい。それに、おもしろいです　→　Mr./Ms. Watanabe is kind. And also, he/she is interesting.
  • 日本は人がおおいです。それに、来るまもおおいです　→　Japan has many people. And in addition there are many cars too.

docs.title: う-Verb (Negative-Past)
docs.text:
The あ form + ない is used to make the present / future negative form for regular verbs.

Examples

  • すわる　→　すわらない
  • うたう　→　うたわない
  • あるく　→　あるかない
  • はなす　→　はなさない
  • うつ　→　うたない
  • しぬ　→　しなない
  • とぶ　→　とばない
  • やすむ　→　やすまない
  • およぐ　→　およがない

docs.title: Exceptions:
docs.text: • ある　→　ない

docs.title: る-Verb (Negative-Past)
docs.text:
In order to form the negative past form of る-Verbs, you will need to remove the る, and then follow it with the auxiliary verb ない (or ます), conjugated into their past forms. This will either be なかった.

Examples

  • 食べる　→　食べなかった
  • 見る　→　見なかった
  • ねる　→　ねなかった

docs.title: Between
docs.text:
あいだ meaning 'between' must be structured in the following way:

  • The dog is between ITEM 1 and ITEM 2

Example

  • いぬはITEM1とITEM2のあいだにます → The dog is between item 1 and item 2

docs.title: あんまり
docs.text:
Previously, I learned that あんまり means 'not that much.'. It also means 'not that often' and is used with negative verbs. You can almost think of あんまり as the opposite of よく

Examples

  • あんまり東京に行きます → I don't go to Tokyo often.
  • あんまりバナナを食べます → I don't eat bananas often.

docs.title: い Adjectives
docs.text:
い adjectives all have one thing in common: they all end in い

Important

  • い adjectives will always have the い outside of the kanji. If the い is inside the kanji, it is not an い adjective.
  • い adjectives must never be followed by だ. This is due to だ only being able to conjugate with nouns (which な-Adjectives originally are)

docs.title: Modifying い Adjectives
docs.text:
To modify a word, they are simply placed in front of it

Examples

  • たかいｋるま　→　an expensive car
  • おもしろいテレビ　→　an interesting TV
  • あかいりんご　→　a red apple
  • ちいさい猫　→　a small cat
  • おいしいピザ　→　delicious pizza

docs.title: い Adjectives Polite Form
docs.text:
い adjectives can be made into the polite form by simply adding です to the end.

Examples

  • あついです　→　hot
  • きょうは、あついです　→　It's hot today.

docs.title: い Adjectives Causal Form
docs.text:
い adjectives can be made into the casual form by simply removing the です at the end.

Examples

  • あつい　→　hot
  • きょうは、あつい　→　It's hot today.

docs.title: Making い Adjectives Past Tense
docs.text:
い adjectives can be made into past tense by taking the い off the end and adding かった. This works for the negative and positive forms of the adjective

Examples

あたらしい　→　new
あたらしかった　→　was new

あたらしくない　→　not new
あたらしくなかった　→　was not new

docs.title: い Adjectives Negative Form
docs.text:
い adjectives can be made into the negative form by taking the い off the end and adding くない

Examples

  • あつくないです　→　not hot
  • きょうは、あつくないです　→　It's not hot today.

docs.title: Things To Know
docs.text:
1. Sentence 1 is always the REASON and sentence 2 is the RESULT
  2. Sentence 1 is better sounding as casual form. The politeness of the sentece is determined by sentence 2.

docs.title: Which verb form to use with から sentences
docs.text:
It sounds more natural for the verb in sentence 1 to be informal. The formality of the entire sentence is decided by the verb in sentence 2

However, you can use different forms. Here is a list of the combinations allowed when creating から statements:

Important

You can never have a formal verb in sentence 1 and then an informal verb in sentence 2

There is an easy way to remeber the patterns that are allowed. You can go across the politeness (informal → informal) or (polite → polite). You can also go up in politeness (informal → polite). But you can never go down (polite → informal). Never go down. That is the shortcut.

Example Sentences

In English, we switch between "so", "since", or "because" depending on how you want the sentence to sound. However, the Japanese sentence remains the same regardless of which one is used.

  • 友達がいないから、さびしいです　→　I am lonely because I don't have any friends.
  • 明日東京に行くから、今日スーツケースをかいます　→　I am going to Tokyo tomorrow, so I will buy a suitcase

docs.title: What happens with です?
docs.text:
What happens with です depends on what is directly before the です. If sentence 1 ends with an い adjective (any tense), the です is removed.

Example:

If sentence 1 ends with a な adjective or a noun then です changes to the informal form of です, which is だ

Examples:

docs.title: そして
docs.text: そして means "and" and is used to connect two sentences. と, which also means "and", is only used to connect items in a list and cannot be used to connect sentences

docs.title: The た Form
docs.text:
The informal past tense form (calling it the た form), is made by converting the final hiragana of the dictionary form into various combindations

Examples:

docs.title: Meaning
docs.text:
でしょう is a conjugated form of です, and can also be seen in the contracted form でしょ (more casual).

でしょう is regularly translated to 'right?', or 'probably'. In a broader sense, it just expresses an assertion about something (like です), that the speaker assumes the listener would probably agree with.

Example

彼もおどるでしょう　→ He will probably dance too

docs.title: Uses
docs.text: The と particle can be used to say 'and' as well as 'with'

docs.title: And
docs.text:
The 'and' version of と is always used between two words.

Examples

  • いぬとねこ → dog and cat
  • 貴方と私 → you and I
  • りんごとすし → apples and sushi

docs.title: With
docs.text:
The 'with' version of と is always used after a word, never between.

Examples

  • 田中さんと → with Mr/Mrs. Tanaka
  • まりさんはまことさんと帰ります → Mari will return with Makoto.
  • 僕は小林さんと行きます → I am going with Mr. Kobayashi

docs.title: Modifying な Adjectives
docs.text:
な adjectives must have な after them when directly modifying. They cannot be used to modify unless な comes after them.

Examples

  • きらいなくるま　→　a clean car
  • べんりなみせ　→　a convenient store

docs.title: な Adjectives Polite Form
docs.text:
な adjectives can be made into the polite form by simply adding です to the end.

Examples

  • しずかです　→　quiet
  • きょうは、しずかです　→　It's quiet today.

docs.title: な Adjectives Causal Form
docs.text:
な adjectives can be made into the casual form by simply removing the です at the end and replacing it with だ

Example

  • しずかだ　→　It's quiet.

docs.title: Making な Adjectives Past Tense
docs.text:
な adjectives can be made into past tense by adding でした at the end.

Example

  • しずかでした　→　It was quiet.

docs.title: な Adjectives Negative Form
docs.text:
な adjectives can be made into the negative form by adding ではありません

Examples

  • しずかではありません　→　not quiet
  • きょうは、しずかではありません　→　It's not quiet today.

docs.title: Noun Connector
docs.text:
の can be used to connect two nouns. A noun that has been changed into an adjectived using の is considered a の adjective. A noun cannot describe or modify another noun unless の comes after it.

Example

  • 大学の先生 → a college professor

docs.title: Possessive Connector
docs.text:
の can be used to indicate possession

Example

  • あれは私のぺんです → That over there is my pen.

docs.title: Of
docs.text: の can also mean of

docs.title: Question marker の
docs.text:
This の acts as the か question marker. It's placed after informal verb forms to make a question.

Note

The informal form is almost never used in written form. It's used in informal conversattions (with close friends, family). It should never be used when speaking to someone considered to be of higher social status than the speaker (boss, teacher, etc.).

Examples

  • 東京に行きの？　→　Will you go to Tokyo?
  • 日本にいったの？　→　Did you go to Japan?
  • いえに帰ったの？　→　Did you return home?

docs.title: Using の to create emphasis
docs.text:
When a sentence (not a question) ends in の, and without an updard intonation, it will tend to have more emotion or emphasis.

Important

It's NOT normal for men to use の unless it's a question. Men's response to an informal question with の would end with よ or with just the informal verb

Examples:

docs.title: The ましょう verb ending
docs.text:
The ましょう verb ending is added to the verb root to say things like let's go, or let's eat. In question form, ましょう means Shall we~?

Examples

  • いきましょう → Let's go
  • 帰りましょう → Let's return
  • たべましょう → Let's eat

docs.title: まだ Meaning
docs.text:
まだ means 'not yet'

Info

  • When you have まだ + negative, it means 'didn't ~ not yet ~ yet

docs.title: もう
docs.text: The meaning of もう changes depending on usage.

docs.title: もう means 'already' when placed in front of the positive past tens verbs (た form):
docs.text:
Examples

  • もういきました → I already went there.
  • もう食べました -> I already ate it.
  • もうのみました -> I already drank it.
  • もう読みました -> I already read it.

docs.title: もう also means "already" in front of time related words:
docs.text:
Examples

  • もうなつです -> it's summer already.
  • もうさんじです -> It's already three o' clock.

docs.title: もう can also mean "more" when placed in front of number words:
docs.text:
Examples

  • もう一つ -> one more
  • もう三人 -> three more people

docs.title: もう means "anymore" when placed in front of negative verbs:
docs.text:
Examples

  • もういきません -> I don't want to go anymore.
  • もうたべません -> I'm not going to eat anymore.
  • もうのみまっせん -> I don't drink anymore.

docs.title: もう can also be used with other words with じゃない after them. In this case, もう means "anymore"
docs.text:
Examples

  • もうこどもじゃないです -> I'm not a child anymore.
  • もう私のともだちじゃないです -> They aren't my friends anymore.

docs.title: よ Particle
docs.text:
When a sentence ends with よ it's like adding an exclamation mark. It can be used to convey strong feeling, emotion, and sometimes triumph. It can also be used for emphasis: I'm certain (of what has just been said).

Note

In casual conversation, when said in a neutral tone, よ doesn't add any emotion, however, よ can be assertive when used with a stronger tone.

Examples:

docs.title: よく Meaning
docs.text:
よく means "often" and is placed in front of positive verbs.

Examples

  • よく東京に行きます → I often go to Tokyo.
  • よくバナナを食べますか → Do you often eat bananas?
  • 私はよく日本に帰ります → I often return to Japan.

docs.title: を Particle
docs.text: を is a direct object marker. を must always come after an item which receives or is affected by the action of a verb. No matter where the object that is being eaten, bought, sold, etc., is located in the sentence, the object particle must come after it.

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
Info

I add and remove items from here all the time. I have so many resources that I sometimes forget to add them to this list. With that being said, I'm not using all of these resources currently, they're just here for reference.

These resources are also the online resources I've found or are using (not including textbooks). I don't have Anki explicitly labelled here, but I use Anki everyday.

I'm also not including youtube playlists or channels as I have those stored in youtube already (accessible anywhere)

docs.title: Grammar and Grammar SRS
docs.text:
• Bunpro: Pretty cool. Groups grammar points by N~ level or by textbook. Will essentially make the equivolent of an Anki deck in the UI. I use it more so for repetition but I learn from text books.

  • TokiniAndy Course: He has free youtube videos but the course is amazing. Has graded readers, shadowing practice, vocabulary review, textbook lesson and practice (Genki), and more. I'm not using it anymore as I'm following a different book than genki now.

  • Genki Study Resources By Seth Clydesdale: Amazing resource if you're going through Genki 1. Has a ton of practice for all lessons of Genki 1

  • Tae Kim's Grammar Guide: Don't use this a whole lot, but I've referenced a few things quickly in here so it's pretty good

docs.title: Graded Readers
docs.text: • Tadoku Graded Readers: Free graded books

docs.title: Dictionaries
docs.text:
• Jisho: Tried and true lookup dictionary. Probably use it every day lol

  • jpdb: Have pretty cool features. Also cool for generated Anki decks for anime, novels, etc. Essentially allowing you to skip sentence mining.

docs.title: TV / Movies
docs.text:
• Super Native: Cool site that trains you to hear, read, and speak Japanese from TV and movies.

  • Language Reactor: Kind of like migaku or asbplayer in a way. Embeds directly to youtube or netflix (there are others). Allows you to mine from TV and movies.

  • Kitsunekko: Probably the biggest collection of Japanese subtitles for anime. An absolute lifesaver for immersion.

  • Aniwatch.to: Anime streaming site (mostly use for anime that isn't on any streaming platforms like Crunchyroll, Hidive, Amazon, etc.)

  • Animelon: Can actually stream anime with Japanese subtitles which is pretty cool. Don't use it a ton but.

docs.title: Manga
docs.text: • Mokuro: Allows you to read Japanese manga with Yomichan selectable text inside a browser.

docs.title: Games
docs.text: • Game2Text: Essentially adds the ability to parse Japanese from games

docs.title: Kanji
docs.text: • Kanji Map: Really cool resource for learning stroke patterns

docs.title: Podcasts
docs.text: • Japanese Podcast Spreadsheet: Has a huge list of podcasts in Japanese. There's also a list (starter pack), that's sorted by Japanese level.

docs.title: Sentence Search
docs.text:
• Immersion Kit: Made by game gengo (amazing youtuber!). You can search sentences from anime, games, etc. with translation.

  • Youglish: Sentences sourced from YouTube video subtitles. Great tool for pronunciation as the words are said by native speakers speaking naturally.

docs.title: Browser Extensions
docs.text:
• Yomichan: Yomichan is a browser extension that allows you to look up Japanese words with both the meaning and the reading on web pages with ease.

  • Asbplayer: Load local subtitle files to video streaming sites.
